title_sort: louisa van velsor whitman to walt whitman, [21 april 1873]
title: Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, [21 April 1873]
text: 21 April 1873mondayMondayMy ever dear waltWalti thought i would write to you to day as i didentdidn't know what to doodo with myself i didentdidn't hardly expect a letter to day as i got one saturdaySaturday we have just had our dinner after waiting for georgeGeorge 2 or 3 hours we had a peicepiece of beef yesterday and had it again to day and shall have it till wensdayWednesday or thursdayThursday sometime we have a good peicepiece then it aintain't so bad to have it last so long but this peicepiece is not very good Lou sends orders and eddEddy goes the errands she is down stairs now gets up to breakfast when we are nearly over walke around and lays on the sofa yesterday she went up to the lot to see it georgeGeorge and she it was as much as she could doodo she said i dontdon't know whether she will make out any thing or noti get very much annoyed sometim and very nerviousnervous little things affects me more than it does some people i think since her aunt is here she could dispencedispense with me very easily) the other day Lou was saying how much butter we used in a week and it was so dear she said she was shuresure aunt libbyLibby didentdidn't eat much butter i said dontdon't get any butter when itsit's so high) i dontdon't think eddEdd and i together eats a quarter of a pound in a week he dontdon't get it to eatthe aunty is helpethelped to the best and the largest sometime i feel bad enoughfenough if i was younger i should show some of my dignity now waltWalt write to me to morrow and tell me how you are getting along waltWalt if you think you cantcan't get a house for us to live in dontdon't worry about me i shall live my allotted time) if you ever do get one i think one about the size of what i wrote about would do and wouldentwouldn't cost very much with a cellar under the 2 rooms and not under the shed kichenkitchenbut walterWalter dear if you was only well how glad i would be and i gessguess you would be as glad as igood bie waltWalt Louisa Van Velsor Whitman to Walt Whitman, [21 April 1873]
